bestBHT.bht: Those who do not have love in their hearts for the Lord Jesus are to be cursed, with the phrase Maranatha serving as a watchword to remind them of His imminent coming and the need to be prepared. The connection between love for one another and love for Him is emphasized, and the use of Anathema highlights the seriousness of neglecting this love. This solemn declaration should not be taken lightly, as without love for the Savior, there is no salvation.

Henry Alford: The negation here of the feeling of personal affection, 'has no love in his heart for,' is worthy of note, as connected with the curse which follows.
Let him be Anathema...let him be accursed.

Maran-atha...is probably unconnected with Anathema, added perhaps as recalling some remembrance of the time when Paul was among them: at all events, as a weighty watchword tending to recall to them the nearness of His coming, and the duty of being found ready for it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Love to one another is to be in connection with love to Him above all.
So far from 'saluting' him, I bid him be accursed.
Maranatha: 'the Lord cometh.' A motto or watchword to urge them to preparedness for the Lord's coming.
Albert Barnes: It is implied that there was danger, in their disputes and strifes about minor matters, of neglecting the love of the Lord Jesus, or of substituting attachment to a party in the place of that love to the Saviour which alone could be connected with eternal life.
No matter what any man’s endowments might be...yet if he had not true love to the Lord Jesus, he could not be saved.

There is not a more solemn declaration in the Bible; there is not a more fearful denunciation; there is no one that will be more certainly executed. No matter what we may have...yet if we have not love to the Saviour, we cannot be saved.
Marvin Vincent: It was a reminder of the second coming.
The reason for the use of the Aramaic phrase is unknown.
John Calvin: I expound it in a simple way as follows: 'Let them perish and be cut off, as being the pests of the Church.'

Paul, then, after pronouncing an anathema on those who do not love Christ, deeply affected with the seriousness of the matter, as if he reckoned that he had not said enough, added a term that was in common use among the Jews, and which they made use of in pronouncing a sentence of anathema.
'The Lord is to come,' i.e., will come, to take vengeance on the disobedient and vicious. Hence with the words Anathema Maranatha the Jews began their papers of excommunication.
Philip Schaff: If any man loveth not the Lord that is, the Lord Jesus, let him be Anathema." - 1 Corinthians 16:22

Maran atha. This is the Aramaean or Syriac expression for ‘Our Lord cometh;’ a solemn warning that the approaching Advent of the Lord would see that dreadful curse visited upon such." - 1 Corinthians 16:22

What I mean is, if any man hath not such love of Him who laid down His life for us that he would lay down his own life for Him, rejoicing to be counted worthy to suffer for His name." - 1 Corinthians 16:22
Archibald T. Robertson: The refusal to love Christ (ου φιλε) on the part of a nominal Christian deserves αναθεμα.
This Aramaic phrase means 'Our Lord (μαραν) cometh (αθα)' or, used as a proleptic perfect, 'has come.'
It was a curious blunder in the King James Version that connected Μαραν αθα with Αναθεμα.
John Gill: If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ.... such persons that love not the Lord Jesus, should be rejected by the saints, and separated from their communion; let him be cast out of it, and cut off from it.
Maranatha... put persons in mind of the coming of Christ; either at the destruction of Jerusalem... or of the second coming of Christ to judgment.
All the wicked of the earth shall be accursed by him, and all such that love him not will be bid to depart from him.
John Wesley: If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ... Let him be Anathema."
Anathema signifies a thing devoted to destruction."
The Lord cometh; namely, to execute vengeance upon him.

This curse serves as a weighty watchword, reminding them of the nearness of His coming and the duty of preparedness. Love for one another should be connected with love for Him above all else. The phrase Maranatha, meaning the Lord cometh, is a motto to urge readiness for His coming. It was a curious blunder to connect this phrase with the curse mentioned. The use of Anathema implies that those who neglect the love of the Lord Jesus may face the dreadful curse. This solemn declaration should be taken seriously, for without love for the Savior, we cannot be saved.

Love for one another should be intertwined with love for Him above all. The use of Anathema emphasizes the severity of neglecting this love. Without love for the Savior, there is no salvation.

If anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, they are to be accursed. This strong statement highlights the importance of love for Christ above all else. It serves as a reminder of the impending second coming of the Lord and the need to be prepared for it. By using the Aramaic phrase Maranatha, which means the Lord cometh, the Apostle Paul emphasizes the urgency of being ready for the Lord's arrival. The use of the term Anathema underscores the severity of the consequences for those who lack love for Christ, as it signifies being devoted to destruction. Therefore, the message is clear: love for one another must always be connected to love for the Lord Jesus.

If anyone does not have love for the Lord Jesus Christ, they are to be accursed. The phrase Maranatha is used to remind believers of the imminent second coming of Christ, urging them to be prepared. By connecting love for Christ with the concept of being anathema, Paul emphasizes the severity of the consequences for disregarding this love. It is crucial for believers to prioritize their love for Christ above all else, recognizing that it is intertwined with their love for one another.
